differences.concept_a_point: The chemical reaction inside the primary cell is irreversible
differences.concept_b_point: The chemical reaction inside the secondary cell is reversible

differences.concept_a_point: It cannot be recharged after use
differences.concept_b_point: It can be recharged and reused

differences.concept_a_point: Used in small devices such as torches, toys, radios and small tape recorders
differences.concept_b_point: Used in mobile phones, cameras, computers and emergency lights

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Dry cell (used in TV remotes)
2. Daniel cell (used in laboratories)
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Lead accumulator (used in cars)
2. Lithium-ion battery (used in phones)

differences.concept_a_point: There is a sharing of voltage among appliances
differences.concept_b_point: Each appliance gets the original voltage

differences.concept_a_point: All appliances work simultaneously - if one stops, all stop
differences.concept_b_point: All appliances work independently

differences.concept_a_point: If any appliance gets damaged, all stop working
differences.concept_b_point: If any appliance gets damaged, others continue to work

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Decorative lights (fairy lights)
2. Old Christmas tree lights
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Home electrical wiring (fan, light, TV)
2. Power strips with multiple outlets

differences.concept_a_point: Substances which allow electric current to flow through them easily
differences.concept_b_point: Substances which do not allow electric current to flow through them

differences.concept_a_point: Have free electrons that can move and carry current
differences.concept_b_point: Have tightly bound electrons that cannot move freely

differences.concept_a_point: Used as core of electric wires
differences.concept_b_point: Used to cover electric wires for safety

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Copper (used in electrical wires)
2. Aluminium (used in power lines)
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Rubber (used in wire coating)
2. Plastic (used in switch covers)

differences.concept_a_point: A circuit in which no electric current flows
differences.concept_b_point: A circuit in which electric current flows

differences.concept_a_point: Occurs when the switch is OFF
differences.concept_b_point: Occurs when the switch is ON

differences.concept_a_point: Circuit is incomplete - broken at some point
differences.concept_b_point: Circuit is complete - provides continuous path

differences.concept_a_point:
1. A torch when switched off
2. A broken wire in a circuit
differences.concept_b_point:
1. A glowing bulb in a lamp
2. A running ceiling fan

differences.concept_a_point: Flows from positive (+) to negative (-) terminal
differences.concept_b_point: Flows from negative (-) to positive (+) terminal

differences.concept_a_point: Based on convention established before electrons were discovered
differences.concept_b_point: Based on actual movement of electrons

differences.concept_a_point: Direction is opposite to electron flow
differences.concept_b_point: Direction is opposite to conventional current

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Current direction shown in circuit diagrams
2. Arrow direction on battery symbols
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Electrons moving through copper wire
2. Electrons flowing in a circuit board

differences.concept_a_point: Wire melts and breaks circuit when current exceeds limit
differences.concept_b_point: Automatically trips and breaks circuit in overload

differences.concept_a_point: Needs to be replaced every time it blows
differences.concept_b_point: Can be reset manually - no replacement needed

differences.concept_a_point: Less sensitive to current changes
differences.concept_b_point: More sensitive - detects even slight voltage fluctuation

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Glass tube fuse in old cars
2. Ceramic fuse in plug tops
differences.concept_b_point:
1. MCB in home electrical panel
2. Trip switch in modern distribution boards

questions.source_section: Prepping for PISA - Fuse vs MCB

differences.concept_a_point: A single unit that converts chemical energy to electrical energy
differences.concept_b_point: A combination of two or more cells connected in series

differences.concept_a_point: Provides a small amount of electricity
differences.concept_b_point: Provides more electrical energy for higher power devices

differences.concept_a_point: Typically 1.5V per cell
differences.concept_b_point: Higher voltage (multiple of cell voltage)

differences.concept_a_point:
1. AA cell in TV remote
2. Button cell in watch
differences.concept_b_point:
1. 9V battery (6 cells inside)
2. Car battery (6 cells giving 12V)

differences.concept_a_point: Acts as an insulator - does not conduct electricity
differences.concept_b_point: Acts as a conductor - allows electricity to flow

differences.concept_a_point: Has very few ions to carry electric current
differences.concept_b_point: Contains dissolved salts that provide ions

differences.concept_a_point: Safe to use near electrical appliances
differences.concept_b_point: Dangerous - can cause electric shock

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Distilled water from laboratory
2. Deionized water used in batteries
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Tap water from kitchen sink
2. River or pond water

differences.concept_a_point: Positive electrode (+)
differences.concept_b_point: Negative electrode (-)

differences.concept_a_point: Carbon rod with brass cap acts as anode
differences.concept_b_point: Zinc container acts as cathode

differences.concept_a_point: Conventional current enters through anode
differences.concept_b_point: Conventional current leaves through cathode

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Carbon rod in dry cell
2. Positive plate in car battery
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Zinc case in dry cell
2. Negative plate in car battery

differences.concept_a_point: Converts mechanical energy into electrical energy
differences.concept_b_point: Converts electrical energy into mechanical energy

differences.concept_a_point: Conductor rotates in magnetic field to produce current
differences.concept_b_point: Current through conductor in magnetic field produces rotation

differences.concept_a_point: Input: motion, Output: electricity
differences.concept_b_point: Input: electricity, Output: motion

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Bicycle dynamo (powers headlight)
2. Power station generator
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Ceiling fan motor
2. Washing machine motor

differences.concept_a_point: Uses flowing water to rotate turbines
differences.concept_b_point: Uses burning fossil fuels to produce steam

differences.concept_a_point: Clean energy - no air pollution
differences.concept_b_point: Produces air pollution from burning fuels

differences.concept_a_point: Renewable (water cycle)
differences.concept_b_point: Non-renewable (coal, gas, oil)

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Bhakra Nangal Dam (India)
2. Three Gorges Dam (China)
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Ramagundam Thermal Plant (India)
2. Coal power stations

differences.concept_a_point: Quick on/off operation of circuit
differences.concept_b_point: Keeps circuit open or closed for longer duration

differences.concept_a_point: Toggle or push button mechanism
differences.concept_b_point: Removable key that can be taken out

differences.concept_a_point: Regular daily use for appliances
differences.concept_b_point: Used in experimental circuits and laboratories

differences.concept_a_point:
1. Light switch on wall
2. Power button on TV
differences.concept_b_point:
1. Plug key in physics lab circuits
2. Ignition key holder (similar concept)
